content.description: The crux of this climb is in the first 10' so unless you are comfortable soloing 5.11 with potential to fall into a deep chasm, stick clip the first bolt. Technical underclinging and footwork gains a large edge. From here waltz up the dihedral with lieback and backstep moves (10+). A #0 TCU protects moves to the 2nd bolt.
content.protection: Two bolts and #0 - #3 TCU's or equivalent. Rap anchors at the top.
content.location: This deceptively difficult route ascends the shallow and low angle dihedral just right of Time Out. Approach via the V0 boulder problem to the large ledge. Rappel anchors are at the top.

content.description:
This route stands among the best in the entire Park. Bold, but adequately protected, the signature second pitch offers continuous climbing in a stellar position. Â The remote and beautiful locale and the surprisingly large north face make for a great setting.

Begin near the center of the North Face, at the foot of the base of the rock, on the left side of a large rectangular block.

Pitch 1: Up cracks on the left side of the block to a very large flat ledge (5.8).

Pitch 2: Move up and left to a discontinuous seam/crack (good small tcus and wires) which is followed up past 2 bolts. Move up and right to a large flake, exiting this higher up to reach a 3rd bolt. Head right to eventually gain a narrow ledge system -- belay at the ledge's right end (11b).

Pitch 3: Up a finger crack to its end and head left and up to the summit (5.7+).
content.protection: Bring a good variety of: thin brass, some stoppers, and thin cams to 2 inches.
content.location: 95 foot rap off the back of the formation. Head around the west side of the rock to return to the base.

climbs.name: The Dunce Cap
climbs.fa: Mike Lechlinski, Mari Gingery, John Bachar, Brenda Bachar, & Craig Fry 1982

content.description: The route begins off of a leaning pillar on the north face of the Dunce Cap. Difficult moves off the pillar onto a steep slab lead to a 1/4" bolt (if the bolt is stick clipped the route is not runout). From the bolt traverse right into a straight-up finger crack that is both shallow and deep. Follow the crack to the top.
content.protection: Brass, small - medium stoppers, and cams to 2" provide adequate protection for this varied climb. Slinged horns are solid as an anchor.
